Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a form of censorship that undermines democracy and free speech.
The bill is compared to Orwellian control as depicted in George Orwell's '1984'.
Free speech is essential for holding governments accountable and maintaining a true democracy.
The mainstream media, exempt from the bill, is accused of being the main purveyor of misinformation.
Independent media provides necessary counter-narratives that the bill would suppress.
The bill is perceived as a tool for the government to control public opinion and avoid scrutiny.
The vague definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the bill could lead to excessive censorship by social media platforms.
Notable Quotes: If free speech and freedom of the press are limited to only approved content then of course the public cannot be completely and correctly informed.
The proposed legislation in the bill, through censoring free speech will effectively neuter democracy, leaving behind just a superficial veneer.
The government does not want a well informed public. Instead it wants the public to only think they are well informed by the mainstream media.
